qas.question: What was the procedure called which involved workers to work for a share of the profits?
What difficulty in harvesting cotton required a large labor force?
Besides adults what segment of the southern US population was involved in the harvesting of cotton?
What function of southern schools was created for children to pick cotton?
What part of the southern population worked as sharecroppers?
What was the procedure called which involved the South to work for a share of the profits?
What difficulty in harvesting cotton required a larger economy?
Besides adults what segment of the southern US population was involved in school systems?
What function of southern schools was created for adults to pick cotton?
What part of the southern population worked as farmers?

context: Cotton remained a key crop in the Southern economy after emancipation and the end of the Civil War in 1865. Across the South, <a0_0><b5_0>sharecropping<b5_0/><a0_0/> evolved, in which <a4_0><b9_0>landless<b9_0/><a4_0/> black and white farmers worked land owned by others in return for a share of the profits. Some farmers rented the land and bore the production costs themselves. Until mechanical cotton pickers were developed, cotton farmers needed additional labor to <a1_0><b6_0>hand-pick<b6_0/><a1_0/> cotton. Picking cotton was a source of income for families across the South. Rural and small town school systems had <a3_0><b8_0>split vacations<b8_0/><a3_0/> so <a2_0><b7_0>children<b7_0/><a2_0/> could work in the fields during "cotton-picking."
